text: Good morning, you are not crazy Google is down
Does anyone know where to pull the prefixes for a HubSpot multi language menu? Like /es for spanish for example? Is there a comprehensive list somewhere ?

Hi
We added some <noscript> code into the header and this is how it is rendering it, any advice how this can be resolved? - <https://image.prntscr.com/image/huMaHudLQJWFj0i8PZer1Q.png>
I'm expecting `{{ heading_two.style }}` to have H2 styles from fields.json, but it looks like only H1 styles are applied for some reason.

Oh wow, I would definitely make this as a global module, and add the menu as a field option.
Then the editor can switch the language, and add the correct menu as they’re updating/translating pages.
This will be a maintenance nightmare and not marketer friendly.

Hi :)
Is there a way on HubSpot to show contact to some users in the organization, but still restricting some information (properties)? We have a department where users should be able to see what contacts we already have but in the mean time we do not want them to have access to their phone number or email.
~The answer: "styles" is meant for font-style (bold, italic, and underline), not what I was trying to do.~

We've got trial to CMS Enterprise Hub. For some reason I was informed that we would have a proper middle tier (nodejs, dotnet etc) and database... Am I misinformed? If not, is there documentation on how we can access the middle tier and setup a hello world using dotnet, php etc?

Hey there, I think there was a misunderstanding potentially in the communication.

Let me help clarify.

CMS Hub Enterprise has serverless functions. We currently support nodejs in serverless functions.

We have a few different methods of storing data within HubSpot. HubDB a more table like database. Custom Objects a datastore that enables you to draw associations between your company’s CRM data and custom types of information. We also have the blog, and pages with modules. Which can store your website data.

HubSpot is a SaaS CMS, it is not a general server webhosting platform.

There are a lot of advantages to the CMS as a result of this. Security is managed by HubSpot. HubSpot does a ton of performance optimization, DDOS protection, has a built-in CDN with image resizing and automatic conversion to webp. The CMS is directly integrated with the CRM so your marketing/sales data can power and optimize your CMS Hub website. We have the CLI which enables a continuous integration and deployment workflow and local development.

Also you don’t have to update the CMS, it is always on the latest version.
So to answer your question more concretely, specifically no you cannot run dotnet and PHP. HubSpot uses HubL as it’s templating language. HubL is based on Jinja.

Here’s a high level overview of the CMS:

<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/key-concepts>

Docs on serverless: <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/features/serverless-functions>

HubDB
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/features/hubdb>

HubL
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl>
Hi <@U2H3TT8F2> is this something you might consider doing again at some point?
Hey Sean, we are def planning on running more of these in the future for sure. We will make sure to announce these as they become available. (cc <@UNQ6UDGSJ>)
